KH.content: khōra as a name that announces the Other of the name, not logos, not mythos, neither this nor that, both this & that: “not lying when I say this” is that telling the truth?
KH.linkedContent: khōra as a name that announces the Other of the name, not logos, not mythos, neither this nor that, both this & that: “not lying when I say this” is that telling the truth?

KH.content: participates (while being excluded) in the intelligible in an aporetic way, genre beyond genre
KH.linkedContent: participates (while being excluded) in the intelligible in an aporetic way, genre beyond genre

KH.content: khōra, discourse on genre, genos (ethnos), gens, it is a triton genos [other 2 genus’: 1) immutable 2) sensible]
KH.linkedContent: khōra, discourse on genre, genos (ethnos), gens, it is a triton genos [other 2 genus’: 1) immutable 2) sensible]

KH.content: belonging of genos [true citizens, philosophers, politicians] to proper place guarantees truth of its logos & action, different to Sophists who have no place, wander
KH.linkedContent: belonging of genos [true citizens, philosophers, politicians] to proper place guarantees truth of its logos & action, different to Sophists who have no place, wander

KH.content: Socrates speaks as true citizen while identifying w/ Sophist, feigns, simulacrum: tells you, you alone have place, gives you the floor > excludes himself by himself by giving back the word; no room for specialists of nonplace or simulacrum in the agora
KH.linkedContent: Socrates speaks as true citizen while identifying w/ Sophist, feigns, simulacrum: tells you, you alone have place, gives you the floor > excludes himself by himself by giving back the word; no room for specialists of nonplace or simulacrum in the agora

KH.content: Socrates as khōra, 3rd genus, for he only resembles the genus of those w/ no place
KH.linkedContent: Socrates as khōra, 3rd genus, for he only resembles the genus of those w/ no place

LOBL.content: how could we make a genre work w/out referring to it quotationally?
LOBL.linkedContent: how could we make a genre work w/out referring to it quotationally?

LOBL.content: structure of invagination exposes precariousness of effects of “genre,” “mode, “corpus,” all historical fictions that certify its carte d’identité
LOBL.linkedContent: structure of invagination exposes precariousness of effects of “genre,” “mode, “corpus,” all historical fictions that certify its carte d’identité

BL.content: law beyond sexual & grammatical gender, neutral

F.content: the Thing is encrypted by crypt (for du Moi, self’s safe) not w/in (dans) it; crypted structure of ultimate referent [Thing] means double articulation (history, story) coalesces all these genres: myth, poem, novel, drama, translation > the narrated event never appears
F.linkedContent: the Thing is encrypted by crypt (for du Moi, self’s safe) not w/in (dans) it; crypted structure of ultimate referent [Thing] means double articulation (history, story) coalesces all these genres: myth, poem, novel, drama, translation > the narrated event never appears

DS.content: forms of writing subject to law of hymen (literature, theater, drama, ballet, dance, fable, mimicry), the rule of the cast-aside-reference, the being aside (référence écartée, être à l’écart)
DS.linkedContent: forms of writing subject to law of hymen (literature, theater, drama, ballet, dance, fable, mimicry), the rule of the cast-aside-reference, the being aside (référence écartée, être à l’écart)

DS.content: following Mallarmé, though this [sexual?] difference opens up play of all writing, must still distinguish genres, trace effects of each genre, whose structure is original in each case
DS.linkedContent: following Mallarmé, though this [sexual?] difference opens up play of all writing, must still distinguish genres, trace effects of each genre, whose structure is original in each case

DS.content: [re: specificity of genres] to join mime & dancer (they should be allied but not confused), two attitudes jealous of their respective silences: this is to confront too much difference!
DS.linkedContent: [re: specificity of genres] to join mime & dancer (they should be allied but not confused), two attitudes jealous of their respective silences: this is to confront too much difference!

DS.content: distinct trait of each genre finds itself commanding the work, employs discrepancy in its very structure [will to power], what remains is to find genres communicating
DS.linkedContent: distinct trait of each genre finds itself commanding the work, employs discrepancy in its very structure [will to power], what remains is to find genres communicating

DS.content: different genres don’t fuse into total art (thus Mallarmé’s gripe w/ Wagner)
DS.linkedContent: different genres don’t fuse into total art (thus Mallarmé’s gripe w/ Wagner)

P.content: to go against feast [re: hermeneutic circle of philosophy & art] do not mix genres but extend metaphors (you can always try: question of style) > i.e. feast top to toe, circling step
P.linkedContent: to go against feast [re: hermeneutic circle of philosophy & art] do not mix genres but extend metaphors (you can always try: question of style) > i.e. feast top to toe, circling step

ATIA.content: Lacan’s “generic prematuration of birth,” essential genesis of man’s castration complex > this “generic” trait, man escaping genre, by means of dé-génération (not degeneracy), whose defect engenders symbolic “generation” (law of Name, Father, Speech, Truth, Deceit)
ATIA.linkedContent: Lacan’s “generic prematuration of birth,” essential genesis of man’s castration complex > this “generic” trait, man escaping genre, by means of dé-génération (not degeneracy), whose defect engenders symbolic “generation” (law of Name, Father, Speech, Truth, Deceit)

PS.content: 187 for Artaud, theater not one genre among others, summons totality of existence
PS.linkedContent: 187 for Artaud, theater not one genre among others, summons totality of existence

PIO.content: singularity of event that produces itself by speaking about itself [Derrida’s essay], invents on subject of invention, bringing it about—while also describing generality of its genre, genealogy of its topos, sustaining tradition de inventione
PIO.linkedContent: singularity of event that produces itself by speaking about itself [Derrida’s essay], invents on subject of invention, bringing it about—while also describing generality of its genre, genealogy of its topos, sustaining tradition de inventione

TR.content: [re: Rousseau’s relation to Augustine’s Confessions] mēkhanē of a dramaturgy, supplement of fiction, inscribe in the archive of a new, quasi-literary genre (confessions) > palimpsestuous [insect/incest], encrypted lineage
TR.linkedContent: [re: Rousseau’s relation to Augustine’s Confessions] mēkhanē of a dramaturgy, supplement of fiction, inscribe in the archive of a new, quasi-literary genre (confessions) > palimpsestuous [insect/incest], encrypted lineage

TR.content: machine-like operation of excuse: divides/multiplies, drags guilty into repetition of “last word” > eschatology becomes a genre, inexhaustible eschatology of final words
TR.linkedContent: machine-like operation of excuse: divides/multiplies, drags guilty into repetition of “last word” > eschatology becomes a genre, inexhaustible eschatology of final words

LG.content: “ne pas mêler les genre”
LG.linkedContent: “ne pas mêler les genre”

LG.content: genre—limit drawn—norms, interdictions not far behind
LG.linkedContent: genre—limit drawn—norms, interdictions not far behind

LG.content: 1) genre as phusis, a biological genre, or a human genre, genre of all that is general 2) genre as non-natural, as typology, associated w/ technē, thesis, nomos (i.e. literary, artistic genre)
LG.linkedContent: 1) genre as phusis, a biological genre, or a human genre, genre of all that is general 2) genre as non-natural, as typology, associated w/ technē, thesis, nomos (i.e. literary, artistic genre)

LG.content: law of law of genre: principle of contamination, parasitical economy, participation w/out belonging
LG.linkedContent: law of law of genre: principle of contamination, parasitical economy, participation w/out belonging

LG.content: can one identify a work of art if it doesn’t bear the mark of a genre?
LG.linkedContent: can one identify a work of art if it doesn’t bear the mark of a genre?

LG.content: no genreless text, always genre & genres
LG.linkedContent: no genreless text, always genre & genres

LG.content: effect of code: in marking itself generically, text unmarks itself (se démarque) > because of trait, text participates in one or several genres
LG.linkedContent: effect of code: in marking itself generically, text unmarks itself (se démarque) > because of trait, text participates in one or several genres

LG.content: genre [i.e. “novel”], singular topos, gathers together the corpus and keeps it from identifying w/ itself > designation [“novel”] does not take part in the corpus
LG.linkedContent: genre [i.e. “novel”], singular topos, gathers together the corpus and keeps it from identifying w/ itself > designation [“novel”] does not take part in the corpus

LG.content: genre-clause (clause de genre): clin d’oeil, écluse (floodgate), clôture qui s’exclut de ce qu’elle inclut, déclasse ce qu’elle permet de classer > unfigurable figure of clusion, forme sans forme, neither sees day nor brings itself to light
LG.linkedContent: genre-clause (clause de genre): clin d’oeil, écluse (floodgate), clôture qui s’exclut de ce qu’elle inclut, déclasse ce qu’elle permet de classer > unfigurable figure of clusion, forme sans forme, neither sees day nor brings itself to light

LG.content: [after Derrida describes the double chiasmatic invagination of La folie du Jour] are all these transgressions permitted by [publishing] law, à l’intérieur de cet espace normé (normed space)? > but in La folie du jour “in whole and in part, the whole is a part (tout et partie , tout est partie)”
LG.linkedContent: [after Derrida describes the double chiasmatic invagination of La folie du Jour] are all these transgressions permitted by [publishing] law, à l’intérieur de cet espace normé (normed space)? > but in La folie du jour “in whole and in part, the whole is a part (tout et partie , tout est partie)”

LG.content: récit of a récit w/out récit, whose visible space is but some border of itself w/out “self”: framing edge w/out content, w/out modal or generic boundaries: law of this textual event
LG.linkedContent: récit of a récit w/out récit, whose visible space is but some border of itself w/out “self”: framing edge w/out content, w/out modal or generic boundaries: law of this textual event

LG.content: degenerescent self-engendering of a récit
LG.linkedContent: degenerescent self-engendering of a récit

LG.content: double chiasmatic invagination of edges excludes pure form, question of literary genre is not a formal one: covers motif of law in general of generation in the natural and symbolic sense
LG.linkedContent: double chiasmatic invagination of edges excludes pure form, question of literary genre is not a formal one: covers motif of law in general of generation in the natural and symbolic sense

LG.content: Derrida includes very elusive, allusive reference to hymen [genre as gender], rapport sans rapport btwn masculine & feminine; genre (Gattung) and marriage in series gattieren, gatten, Gatte/Gattin
LG.linkedContent: Derrida includes very elusive, allusive reference to hymen [genre as gender], rapport sans rapport btwn masculine & feminine; genre (Gattung) and marriage in series gattieren, gatten, Gatte/Gattin

LG.content: [when Blanchot introduces sexual genre] sexual difference (aner, vir—sexual difference does not occur between a species and a genre)
LG.linkedContent: [when Blanchot introduces sexual genre] sexual difference (aner, vir—sexual difference does not occur between a species and a genre)

LG.content: [vis-à-vis Blanchot] as long as I say “yes, yes,” I’m a woman and beautiful, man rendered other: secret and odd hymen > madness of sexual difference, mixing of genres
LG.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Blanchot] as long as I say “yes, yes,” I’m a woman and beautiful, man rendered other: secret and odd hymen > madness of sexual difference, mixing of genres

LG.content: transsexuality permits me, in a more than metaphorical & transferential way, to engender
LG.linkedContent: transsexuality permits me, in a more than metaphorical & transferential way, to engender

LG.content: [vis-à-vis Blanchot] I bring forth to light (donne le jour) precisely the law as the right-to-sight (droit de voir), this law has “me” at its/her disposal? > the “I” sans “I” of narrative voice does not take place, engenders the lawmen [panoptic demand: synopsis]
LG.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Blanchot] I bring forth to light (donne le jour) precisely the law as the right-to-sight (droit de voir), this law has “me” at its/her disposal? > the “I” sans “I” of narrative voice does not take place, engenders the lawmen [panoptic demand: synopsis]

LG.content: double affirmation not foreign to the genre, genius or spirit of law: no double affirmation w/out light of day and daylight becoming law > madness of the day
LG.linkedContent: double affirmation not foreign to the genre, genius or spirit of law: no double affirmation w/out light of day and daylight becoming law > madness of the day

LG.content: [vis-à-vis Blanchot] embrace the knees of the law > genous, je nous
LG.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Blanchot] embrace the knees of the law > genous, je nous

LG.content: law demands a testimony oriented by a sense [genre] of history, ordonné par la raison and unity of “I think (je pense)”: originally synthetic apperception accompanying all representations
LG.linkedContent: law demands a testimony oriented by a sense [genre] of history, ordonné par la raison and unity of “I think (je pense)”: originally synthetic apperception accompanying all representations

LG.content: that “I” does not always accompany itself > radically persecutes the law
LG.linkedContent: that “I” does not always accompany itself > radically persecutes the law

LG.content: the law plays too, she plays upon her generation and genre, à naître [n’être] comme personne (born like anybody or nobody) > born of the one for whom she becomes the law
LG.linkedContent: the law plays too, she plays upon her generation and genre, à naître [n’être] comme personne (born like anybody or nobody) > born of the one for whom she becomes the law

LG.content: “a récit?” will not have been exemplary, w/ regard to the whole > contre-exemplaire de tout ——genre always plays role of order’s principle: resemblance, analogy, identity and difference, taxonomic classification
LG.linkedContent: “a récit?” will not have been exemplary, w/ regard to the whole > contre-exemplaire de tout ——genre always plays role of order’s principle: resemblance, analogy, identity and difference, taxonomic classification

LG.content: l’épreuve of a récit brought to light the madness of genre—spinning (faire tourner) Peterson’s genre-disc, comme un soleil fou > dividing borders btwn literature and its others
LG.linkedContent: l’épreuve of a récit brought to light the madness of genre—spinning (faire tourner) Peterson’s genre-disc, comme un soleil fou > dividing borders btwn literature and its others

LG.content: “this is the whole of it,” only what “I” see, kneeling [à genoux] at edge of literature, “le loi en somme, ce que ‘je’ voit et que ‘je’ dit que je vois en un récit où je/nous somme”
LG.linkedContent: “this is the whole of it,” only what “I” see, kneeling [à genoux] at edge of literature, “le loi en somme, ce que ‘je’ voit et que ‘je’ dit que je vois en un récit où je/nous somme”

ATAP.content: quoting title, a genre, genre making fun of a genre [re: Kant’s “Of an Overlordly Tone Recently Adopted in Philosophy”]
ATAP.linkedContent: quoting title, a genre, genre making fun of a genre [re: Kant’s “Of an Overlordly Tone Recently Adopted in Philosophy”]

SPEC.content: strategy [Freud’s speculation] whose finality’s not clear, no known genre, it overflows, thus the hypothesis, the athesis of athesis > asking questions in the dark: Freud’s phosphorescent antennae
SPEC.linkedContent: strategy [Freud’s speculation] whose finality’s not clear, no known genre, it overflows, thus the hypothesis, the athesis of athesis > asking questions in the dark: Freud’s phosphorescent antennae
